title: Erdős Problem #1015: Partitioning 2-Colored Complete Graphs
description: What is f(t), the minimum leftover vertices when partitioning any 2-colored Kₙ into vertex-disjoint monochromatic Kₜ's? Burr-Erdős-Spencer (1975) proved f(t) = R(t, t-1) + x where 0 ≤ x < t, showing f(t)^{1/t} → 4 (not 1) and f(t) is not O(t).

overview.historicalContext: This problem, originally posed by Moon (1966), asks about efficiently partitioning the edges of a 2-colored complete graph using monochromatic cliques. Moon proved f(3) = 4 for n ≥ 8, meaning when partitioning 2-colored Kₙ into monochromatic triangles, at most 4 vertices remain uncovered. Erdős noted f(t) ≪ 4^t by comparison with Ramsey numbers, and asked whether f(t)^{1/t} → 1 or f(t) ≪ t.
overview.problemStatement: Let f(t) be minimal such that, in any two-coloring of the edges of Kₙ, the edges can be partitioned into vertex-disjoint monochromatic copies of Kₜ (not necessarily the same color) with at most f(t) vertices remaining. Estimate f(t). Is f(t)^{1/t} → 1? Is f(t) ≪ t?
overview.proofStrategy: Burr, Erdős, and Spencer (1975) proved an exact formula: for n sufficiently large depending on t, f(t) = R(t, t-1) + x(t,n) where 0 ≤ x(t,n) < t and n + 1 ≡ R(t,t-1) + x (mod t). This shows f(t) ≈ R(t, t-1), which grows like 4^t/√t, answering both questions negatively.
keyInsights: f(t) depends on the Ramsey number R(t, t-1), not just t
Moon's f(3) = 4 is the first non-trivial case
The exact formula involves a modular correction term x(t,n)
f(t) grows exponentially, not linearly in t

conclusion.summary: Burr, Erdős, and Spencer completely resolved this problem in 1975 by proving an exact formula: f(t) = R(t, t-1) + x(t,n) where the correction term x depends on n mod t. This shows f(t) grows like the Ramsey number R(t, t-1) ≈ 4^t/√t.
conclusion.implications: The result answers both of Erdős's questions negatively: f(t)^{1/t} → 4 (not 1), and f(t) grows exponentially (not linearly). This connects the clique partition problem directly to Ramsey theory.
openQuestions: Exact values of f(t) for specific small t beyond t=3
Algorithmic complexity of finding optimal partitions
